questions.text: A 30-year-old lactating mother presents with fever & pain in her left breast, which appears as below. On examination of the affected side, there is local warmth,  point tenderness over the dependent area, and a positive fluctuation test. There is no palpable lump or skin thinning. There is mild axillary lymphadenopathy on the affected side. The contralateral breast is normal. What is the management plan for this patient?

choices.text: Incision and Drainage after confirming with an ultrasound
Broad spectrum antibiotics only  after confirming with an ultrasound
Aspiration under USG guidance and antibiotics - Repeated aspiration if necessary
Punch biopsy under ultrasound guidance followed by a course of IV antibiotics

questions.solution:
The given case scenario points towards a diagnosis of breast abscess. The latest guidelines for the management of breast abscess specify that multiple aspirations under antibiotic cover should be attempted before an incision and drainage is done. This often allows resolution without the need for an incision scar and also allows the patient to continue breastfeeding.

Mastitis occurs due to the growth of staphylococcus or streptococcus due to breast milk stasis. This occurs secondary to blockage of lactiferous duct or due to incomplete emptying of breast milk or due to retracted nipple. Overgrowth of these bacteria results in the development of breast abscess.

It is commoner in new mothers at the beginning of lactation who are inexperienced with breastfeeding or during weaning when nipple trauma occurs due to the infant's growing teeth. 

Signs and symptoms of this condition involve:

  • Fever and malaise
  • Localized pain and tenderness 
  • Redness and swelling of the affected breast
  • Fluctuation test positive due to pus in the abscess. It is a late sign.

The initial treatment should involve providing pain relief with analgesics. The abscess should then be localized preferably under USG guidance and percutaneous aspiration carried out. The pus should be sent for microbiological examination to find the organism and antibiotic sensitivity. Repeated aspirations may be carried out under antibiotics cover if needed.

In some conditions mentioned below, the breast abscess may be unresponsive to repeated aspirations and antibiotic cover. In such cases, incision and drainage is performed. The conditions include:

  • Presence of thick pus
  • Bacteria resistant to antibiotics
  • If just superficial part has been aspirated in the presence of a multiloculated abscess
  • A non-healing breast abscess due to tuberculosis of breast or Inflammatory carcinoma of the breast, or an immunocompromised host.

A homeless, alcoholic man presented with altered sensorium and rapid shallow breathing. His abdomen is distended, and fluid thrill is positive. Icterus and multiple spider hemangiomas are noted. You also find multiple needle tracks on his arms and a half-empty strip of paracetamol tablets in his pocket. The liver function test results are given below. What is the most likely cause for this patient's presentation?

Total Bilirubin: 3.2mg/dL

Aspartate transaminase (AST): 80 IU/L

Alanine transaminase (ALT): 25 IU/L

Alkaline phosphatase (ALP): 200 IU/L

γ-glutamyl transferase (GGT): 68 IU/L

Albumin: 2.6 g/dL

Discriminant function (DF): 34

Fingerstick blood glucose: 50 mg/dL.
questions.solution:
The most likely cause for this patient's presentation is alcoholic liver disease. 

This patient's presentation of altered consciousness with jaundice (scleral icterus) and signs of liver cirrhosis (distended abdomen, spider angiomas) is suggestive of hepatic encephalopathy. The AST: ALT ratio in this patient is > 2:1 which is characteristic of alcoholic liver disease (Normal levels: AST- 10-40 IU/L, ALT - 10-40 IU/L). This is because there is a deficiency of pyridoxal 5'- phosphate in alcoholics. 

An AST: ALT ratio >2:1 is suggestive, whereas a ratio >3:1 (as in this patient) is highly suggestive, of alcoholic liver disease.

In this patient with alcoholic liver cirrhosis, not eating his meals has resulted in hypoglycemia and dehydration, precipitating hepatic encephalopathy. 

Discriminant function (DF) is calculated using prothrombin time and bilirubin level. It is also known as the Maddrey score and it assesses the severity and mortality risk in alcoholic hepatitis. DF ≥ 32 indicates severe disease.

Other options:

Option B: This patient's homelessness and multiple needle tracks suggestive of IV drug abuse put him at risk of contracting viral hepatitis. In acute viral hepatitis, the aminotransferases are often elevated > 500 IU (400-4000 IU/L) due to extensive cell injury.

Option C: In autoimmune hepatitis, aminotransferase levels are elevated and fluctuate in the range of 100-1000 IU/L. Autoimmune hepatitis may present as acute or chronic hepatitis or cirrhosis. Commonly associated symptoms include fatigue, anorexia, pruritis, arthralgias, upper abdominal discomfort, skin rashes including acne among others. 

Option D: Finding an empty strip of paracetamol arises suspicion of paracetamol overdose/ acute acetaminophen poisoning. However, in acute acetaminophen poisoning, the aminotransferases are elevated > 1000 IU and may exceed 10,000 IU/L due to acute hepatocellular injury.

questions.text: Precordial auscultation of a cyanotic newborn revealed a holosystolic murmur heard at the lower left parasternal area. On probing, it is found that the mother had had an episode of unusual behavior two years ago. She had an irritable mood and often spoke fast with pressured speech. She would stay up all night working on bizarre ideas but never feel fatigued. She had been started on medications which she continued to take through her pregnancy fearing a relapse but doesn't know the name of the tablet. Which of the following findings will be found on the chest X-ray of this baby?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of cyanotic congenital heart disease with an antenatal history suggesting lithium intake for mania suggests Ebstein's anomaly. The characteristic finding is that of a box-shaped heart on chest x-ray.

Ebstein anomaly is characterized by the downward displacement of the tricuspid valve into the right ventricle. This results in a thin-walled, low-pressure, atrialized right ventricular segment due to the anomalous attachment of the tricuspid leaflets. The tricuspid valve tissue is dysplastic causing tricuspid regurgitation. This regurgitation leads to the enlargement of the right atrium producing the characteristic box-shaped heart.

On auscultation, the S1 is widely split due to delayed closure of the anomalous tricuspid valve. The second heart sound is usually normal but may be widely split if there is a right bundle branch block. The tricuspid regurgitation results in the characteristic holosystolic murmur that is heard maximally at the left lower parasternal area. It may sometimes be heard at the apex due to the displaced location of the valve.

Additionally, the right ventricle is hypoplastic, which leads to decreased pulmonary outflow resulting in functional pulmonary atresia. As a result, blood shunts through the foramen ovale/atrial septal defect (ASD) presenting with cyanosis at birth.

A snowman appearance is seen in older children with total anomalous pulmonary venous return. The anomalous pulmonary vein joining the brachiocephalic vein on the top, and the superior vena cava on the right form the head of the snowman; the body of the snowman is formed by the enlarged right atrium.

An egg-on-side appearance is seen in the transposition of great arteries due to mild cardiomegaly and narrow mediastinum.

A boot-shaped heart (also called Coeur en sabot) is seen in Tetrology of Fallot (TOF). Here, there is right ventricular hypertrophy which causes an uplifted rounded apical shadow facing the left chest wall.

Other options:

Option A: Snowman appearance is seen in older children with total anomalous pulmonary venous return. The anomalous pulmonary vein joining the brachiocephalic vein on the top, and the superior vena cava on the right form the head of the snowman; the body of the snowman is formed by the enlarged right atrium.

Option B: Egg on side appearance is seen in the transposition of great arteries due to mild cardiomegaly and narrow mediastinum.

Option C: Boot-shaped heart (also called Coeur en sabot) is seen in Tetrology of Fallot (TOF). In TOF, there is right ventricular hypertrophy which causes an uplifted rounded apical shadow facing the left chest wall.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with severe pain in the right knee for a duration of two weeks. He also complains of a mild grade fever during this period. On examination, the knee joint is swollen, mildly tender but there is no erythema or warmth. X-ray of the knee joint shows linear calcifications in the cartilages of the knee joint but no osteophytes or reduction in the joint space. The synovial fluid from the joint is aspirated for analysis. WBC count in the aspirated fluid is 15,000 cells/μL with 50% neutrophils. The aspirate shows crystals that appear to be rhomboid, 0.5 to 5 μm in the greatest dimension, and positively birefringent.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given history and investigations are suggestive of calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition disease (CPPD).

Calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition disease (CPPD), also known as pseudo-gout and chondrocalcinosis, is usually seen in the elderly and becomes more common with increasing age. It is classified into the sporadic (idiopathic), hereditary, and secondary types.

  • In both sporadic and familial pseudogout, germline mutations in the ANKH gene result in increased production and deposition of inorganic phosphate in the tissue cartilages. 
  • CPPD in younger individuals (<50 years) is usually secondary and is associated with previous joint damage, hyperparathyroidism, hemochromatosis, hypomagnesemia, hypothyroidism, ochronosis, and diabetes.

Patients with CPPD may be asymptomatic or present with acute, subacute, or chronic joint disease. The joint involvement may be monoarticular or polyarticular. The knee is the most commonly affected joint. There may be associated systemic symptoms such as low-grade fever and fatigue. The radiodense deposition of calcium pyrophosphate crystals in a linear fashion in the cartilage is a characteristic X-ray finding, giving rise to the terminology, chondrocalcinosis.

Definitive diagnosis includes synovial fluid analysis. The synovial aspirate usually shows an increased WBC count ranging in thousands (a mean of 24,000 cells/μL) with a predominance of neutrophils. The aspirate is also characteristic of rhomboid crystals, 0.5 to 5 μm in the greatest dimension which are positively birefringent under polarized microscopy. This means that the crystals appear blue when their optical axis is parallel to the polarizer and yellow when perpendicular.

Other options :

Option A: Calcium apatite deposition disease (CADD) is usually seen in the elderly with chronic osteopathy. This patient's X-ray knee shows normal joint space with no osteophytes ruling out chronic osteoarthritis. In CADD, X-ray shows intra-articular or periarticular calcification but they are not linear like seen in CPPD. Synovial fluid analysis in calcium apatite deposition disease will show a leukocyte count <2000 cells/μL with a predominance of mononuclear cells. The individual crystals are very small and can be viewed only under electron microscopy. They are nonbirefringent.

Option B: Septic arthritis presents with an acute onset of severe joint pain and immobility, associated with high-grade fever. This patient has a mild-grade fever and subacute onset of symptoms. Further synovial aspirate in septic arthritis usually shows WBC count > 50,000 cells/μL with >75% neutrophils.

Option C: Gout is also a metabolic arthropathy caused due to hyperuricemia. In gout, the synovial aspirate shows needle-shaped crystals with negative birefringence (image below).

questions.text: You are participating in a village camp for screening pre-hypertension and hypertension in 100 individuals over 40 years of age without any other co-morbidities. You record the BP for all of them and find it to follow a normal distribution. The mean SBP is 120mmHg with a standard deviation of 10mmHg. You plan to conduct a short session for those whose BP is 130mmHg or more and advise them regarding non-pharmacological methods to reduce BP using the lifestyle modification approach. How many individuals will you conduct a session for?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, with a normal distribution graph with a mean SBP of 120 mmHg and a standard deviation of 10mmHg, almost 16 individuals will have an SBP of more than 130mmHg. As per your plan you can conduct a session for these individuals.

In a normal distribution curve:

  • 68% of the sample population lie between mean ± 1 SD.
  • 95.5% of the sample population lie between mean ± 2 SD
  • 99.7% of the sample population lie between mean ± 3 SD

So the number of individuals having their SBP more than 130mmHg (>mean + 1SD) can be calculated as follows:

  • Step 1: Subtract the individuals having BP within mean ± 1 SD (68%) from the total number of individuals (100). This comes out to 32 individuals (100 -68 ).
  • Step 2: These 32 individuals are symmetrically distributed as
    • 16 individuals having SBP less than Mean - 1SD. This means having an SBP less than 120 - (10). Implying less than 110mmHg.
    • The other 16 individuals having SBP more than the mean +1 SD. This means having an SBP of more than 120 + (10). Implying SBP more than 130 mmHg.

Therefore, you would conduct a health education seminar for these 16 individuals who have SBP >130 mmHg.

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.

Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

  • Defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation
  • Has mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1
  • Mean = median = mode
  • Symmetric and have bell-shaped curves with a single peak
  • Total area under the curve is 1
  • Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails
  • No skew in the curve
  • Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution
  • The empirical rule of a normal distribution:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

questions.text: A 4-year-old child has a history of biting his lips and fingers. On evaluation, you notice lip lacerations, missing portions of fingers of his hands, and developmental delay. On inquiry, the parents say that two male cousins on the mother's side with similar complaints have been diagnosed with a genetic disorder. Lab reports reveal hyperuricemia. Which enzyme is most likely deficient in this child?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of self-mutilating behavior, delayed developmental milestones, positive family history and hyperuricemia is highly suggestive of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. It occurs due to the complete deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT) involved in the salvage pathway.

Purines produced in the body or introduced through diet can be converted to nucleoside triphosphates to be reused by the body. This pathway is called the salvage pathway for purines and is shown below

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder due to a complete deficiency of the HGPRT enzyme. This deficiency results in an inability to salvage hypoxanthine or guanine resulting in increased levels of phospho-ribosyl pyrophosphate (PRPP) and decreased levels of inosine monophosphate (IMP) and guanosine monophosphate (GMP). There is increased de novo purine synthesis which produces excessive amounts of uric acid.

The clinical features include compulsive self-mutilation, intellectual disability, delayed milestones, dystonic movements, and hyperuricemia. The excess uric acid can form kidney stones (urolithiasis) or deposit in joints as urate crystals (gouty arthritis).

The treatment of this condition includes:

  • Allopurinol or febuxostat for hyperuricemia
  • Behavioral management using restraints for self-mutilation
  • High fluid intake, reduced fructose and purine intake

Partial deficiency of HGPRT leads to Kelley-Seegmiller syndrome.

Other options:

Option A:Purine nucleoside phosphorylase deficiency leads to severe T cell deficiency with normal B cell function. Patients present with autoimmune diseases and opportunistic infections.

Option C: Adenine phosphoribosyltransferase (APRT) is another enzyme along with HGPRT to be involved in the salvage of purine bases to nucleotides. 

Option D: Adenosine deaminase deficiency leads to sparse or defective T cells and B cells. Patients suffer from sever immunodeficiency and often succumb to fatal infections. 

 

Related Pearl: Purine salvage deficiencies: Lesch-Nyhan syndrome and Adenosine deaminase deficiency(SCID)

Severe Combined Immunodeficiency(SCID):

Adenosine deaminase enzyme deficiency is one of the major cause of SCID. It is also called as Glanzmann–Riniker syndrome.

SCID patients are usually affected by severe bacterial, viral, or fungal infections early in life and often present with interstitial lung disease, chronic diarrhea, and failure to thrive.

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome:

It is due to deficiency of the enzyme Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase(HGPRT). It is an X-linked recessive disease.

Clinical features:

  • Intellectual disability
  • Self-mutilation
  • Aggression
  • Hyperuricemia 
  • Gout

Treatment:

  • Allopurinol
  • Febuxostat

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presents with complaints of dull, aching headaches and difficulty seeing the class board for the past few months. He is below the 25th percentile for height and weight. Deep tendon reflexes are sluggish. Eye examination reveals papilledema and bitemporal hemianopsia. An MRI shows a mixed cystic and solid lesion in the suprasellar region with calcification. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette of a calcified cystic lesion in the suprasellar region and symptoms of headache with bitemporal hemianopsia is suggestive of craniopharyngioma. 

It is a benign tumor that is derived from Rathke’s pouch, a diverticulum arising from the embryonic buccal cavity, from which the anterior pituitary gland develops. It is most commonly seen in children (5–15 years); however, it exhibits a bimodal incidence and can also be seen in adults (55–65 years). 

These tumors are usually large and heterogeneous and have both solid and cystic components and occur within the suprasellar area. The cysts contain a cholesterol-rich, thick, brownish-yellow fluid that is comparable to "machine oil."

Clinical presentation:

  • Features of raised intracranial pressure, including headache that is a continuous dull-aching type and papilledema
  • Visual impairment, with decreased acuity or visual field abnormalities (bitemporal hemianopsia)
  • Endocrinologic abnormalities, such as growth failure, hypothyroidism, and delayed sexual maturation due to pituitary hypofunction

Radiological findings:   

  • CT: May show calcifications associated with the solid and cystic wall components.
  • MRI:

Other options: 

Option B- Pituitary macroadenomas (with cystic degeneration or necrosis) usually have an intrasellar epicenter with pituitary fossa enlargement rather than suprasellar epicenter. Calcifications are mostly absent, in contrast to craniopharyngiomas. In addition, on imaging, indentation at the diaphragma sellae gives rise to snowman/figure of eight appearance/cottage loaf.

Option C- Optic nerve gliomas can be seen involving the optic nerves, optic chiasm, and optic tracts and can be differentiated from craniopharyngiomas with the help of calcifications that are characteristically seen in the latter. They are a type of pilocytic astrocytes that occur in childhood.

Option D- Rathke's cleft cysts appear completely cystic with a smooth, thin wall and no calcifications on MRI. They are mostly seen in the intrasellar region; this is in contrast to craniopharyngiomas, which are mostly suprasellar.

questions.text: A 24-year-old athlete came from abroad after winning a competition. He is fond of street food and would try anything he gets his hands on. But now he complains of greasy foul-smelling stools and abdominal cramps. Microscopic examination of stool concentrate revealed cysts and binucleate, tetra-flagellate trophozoites as shown. Appropriate treatment was prescribed for 5days to be taken thrice daily. Two days later he presented with flushing, palpitation, headache, tachycardia, and nausea. He reported having alcohol after initiation of therapy. What is the likely mechanism of the drug which was prescribed?

choices.text: Inhibition of protein synthesis by binding to 30S ribosome

questions.solution:
The above given clinical scenario is suggestive of disulfiram-like reaction following medication taken to treat giardiasis (stool examination shows binucleate, tetra-flagellate trophozoites) in this patient. Metronidazole acts by forming free-radical metabolites.

It is well known to cause a disulfiram-like reaction when alcohol is taken during or within 3 days of therapy.

Metronidazole acts selectively against anaerobic and microaerophilic organisms. It enters the cell and is reduced to form a nitro radical. This radical competes with the PFOR(pyruvate ferredoxin oxidoreductase) enzyme used by these organisms to carry out pyruvate metabolism(since these do not have mitochondria). It inhibits the cellular metabolism of these organisms, causing death.

Other drugs used against giardiasis and their mechanism of action includes 

  • Tinidazole has similar mechanism as metronidazole. Has longer t1/2 and longer duration of action. It is given as 2g once by mouth
  • Nitazoxanide has PFOR inhibiting property. It is given 500mg twice daily for 3 days
  • Paromomycin is an aminoglycoside. It is given to pregnant women with giardiasis. It acts by binding to 30S ribosomes and inhibiting protein synthesis.

Drugs causing disulfiram like reaction are :

  • Metronidazole
  • Cefoperazone
  • 1st generation sulfonylureas
  • Griseofulvin
  • Procarbazine.

These drugs inhibit aldehyde dehydrogenase, similar to disulfiram. When alcohol is combined with these drugs, acetaldehyde accumulates and causes unpleasant reactions like

  • Flushing
  • Sweating
  • Tachycardia
  • Hypotension
  • Nausea, vomiting
  • Dizziness
  • Headache.

questions.text: A female patient presents with disturbed sleep and difficulty concentrating at work for several months. She awakens early and feels fatigued all day. She is too anxious to fall asleep because she believes her neighborhood is unsafe. She is a single parent and worries about her son's school performance and their finances. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is generalized anxiety disorder (GAD).

Generalized anxiety disorder is defined as excessive anxiety and worry about several events or activities for most days during at least a 6-month period.

It is more commonly seen in females, with onset usually in teenage or early adult life. It is often seen coexisting with another anxiety disorder (such as social phobia, specific phobia, panic disorder), major depressive disorder, or substance abuse disorder. 

Areas of the brain implicated in the pathogenesis of generalized anxiety disorder include the occipital lobe, basal ganglia, the limbic system, and the frontal cortex.

Diagnosis of generalized anxiety disorder is made using the DSM-V criteria-

  1. Excessive anxiety and worry about a number of events, occurring more days than not for at least 6 months, about a number of events or activities.
  2. Difficulty in controlling the worry.
  3. The anxiety and worry are associated with three or more of the following six symptoms (with at least some symptoms having been present for more days than not for the past 6 months):
    1. Restlessness or feeling keyed up or on edge
    2. Being easily fatigued
    3. Difficulty concentrating or mind going blank
    4. Irritability
    5. Muscle tension
    6. Sleep disturbance (difficulty falling or staying asleep, or restless, unsatisfying sleep).
  4. The symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other areas of functioning.
  5. The disturbance is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition
  6. The disturbance is not better explained by another medical disorder.  

Treatment of generalized anxiety disorder includes psychotherapy and pharmacotherapy including benzodiazepines, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, buspirone, and venlafaxine.  

Other options:

Option B: Dependent personality disorder (DPD) is an anxious personality disorder characterized by an inability to be alone. People with DPD develop symptoms of anxiety when they’re not around others. They rely on other people for comfort, reassurance, advice, and support.

Option C: Social anxiety disorder/social phobia specifically involves the fear of social situations, unlike general anxiety disorder which involves anxiety about a lot of different things.

Option D: Panic disorder includes episodes of acute intense attacks of anxiety accompanied by feelings of impending doom. Generalized anxiety disorder is often confused with panic disorder and can be differentiated by the absence of spontaneous panic attacks.

A 64-year-old woman, Mrs. Sharmila is brought to the emergency room, with a 3-day history of fever, worsening confusion, agitation, and disorientation. Her husband says that he also noticed drooping of her mouth on the left side, since this morning and immediately rushed her to the hospital. She has no other significant past history and no recent foreign travel. Examination reveals a pulse rate of 90 per minute, BP of 142/90 mm of Hg, and a temperature of 100.3F. She is drowsy and agitated but is able to follow directions. She has some neck rigidity. Weakness is present on the left side of the face with drooping of the angle of the mouth, inability to close her eyelids, and inability to furrow her forehead on the same side. The rest of the neurological examination is normal. CSF tap is performed and the lab results are attached below. What is the most likely causative agent in this condition?

CSF analysis-

WBC count 470/μL
Differential of WBC  Predominantly lymphocytes
Gram stain  Negative
Glucose 60 mg/dL
Protein 90 mg/dL 
Opening pressure 200 mm of water
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette and CSF analysis findings are strongly suggestive of viral encephalitis. The most common cause of sporadic acute viral encephalitis in the world is the Herpes simplex virus (HSV). Specifically, Herpes simplex virus-1. 

It is a DNA virus belonging to the Herpesviridae family. It can cause sporadic acute encephalitis in individuals of all age groups with no gender predilection. A majority of these patients are already infected with HSV. Therefore, encephalitis is thought to occur by means of direct neuronal transmission of the virus to the brain via the trigeminal or olfactory nerve. 

Clinically, patients with acute viral encephalitis present with-

  • Constitutional symptoms- fever and headache
  • Confusion, agitation, change in personality, and altered consciousness
  • Signs of meningeal irritation such as neck rigidity
  • Focal neurological deficits involving any part of the body ranging from ataxia to hemiparesis
  • Cranial nerve deficits such as facial palsy (as seen in this patient)
  • Temporal lobe signs- Characteristic of HSV encephalitis. Includes aphasia, memory loss, and auditory hallucinations
  • Seizures- focal or generalized. 

Laboratory investigation of HSV encephalitis includes-

  • CSF analysis- Increased WBC count with lymphocytic predominance; normal glucose; increased protein; and normal to increased opening pressure

  • HSV DNA in CSF by PCR- Most sensitive method for early diagnosis of HSV encephalitis. It is the investigation of choice.
  • MRI- T2-weighted MRI,  FLAIR, or Diffusion-weighted MRI show high-intensity signals in the temporal regions
  • EEG- A distinctive periodic pattern is seen.

Treatment of HSV encephalitis includes IV. Acyclovir. It is the drug of choice and administered in the dose of 10mg/kg body weight, once every eight hours for 14 to 21 days.

Other options-

Option A- Borrelia burgdorferi is the causative organism of Lyme disease. CNS involvement may be seen in the late stages due to dissemination and is called neuroborreliosis. Patients present with symptoms of diffuse encephalopathy and radiculopathy or meningitis. They include spastic paraparesis, ataxia, cranial nerve palsies, bladder dysfunction, and cognitive impairment. However, in this clinical case, neuroborreliosis is unlikely.

Option B- West Nile Virus may also cause encephalitis. It may also cause other characteristic symptoms such as acute flaccid paralysis. It is seen more commonly in people aged more than 60 years and in immunocompromised. It is less common than sporadic HSV encephalitis and is therefore a less likely cause in this case.

Option D- Neisseria meningitides cause bacterial meningitis. It is unlikely in this case as the CSF analysis suggests a viral etiology.

questions.text: A 25-year-old boxer came to the emergency department after an injury to the hand during a boxing fight. The patient complains of pain, swelling, and tenderness over the base of the thumb. On examination, a restricted thumb movement over the carpometacarpal joint is observed. Based on the history given by the patient, an x-ray of the hand is done and is shown in the figure. Which of the following muscles of the hand causes displacement of the thumb after this fracture?
questions.solution:
In the given case, Xray shows a fracture of the base of the 1st metacarpal also known as Bennet fracture.  It is unstable due to the medial and dorsal pull of the abductor pollicis longus muscle which is inserted on the radial side of the first metacarpal base.

  • Origin:  Posterior surface of the ulnar shaft and adjacent interosseus membrane.
  • Insertion: Splits into two slips. One is attached on trapezium and other on radial surface of base of 1st metacarpal
  • Action: Abducts the metacarpal bone of the thumb and wrist.
  • Innervation: Posterior interosseus nerve (radial nerve)

Opponens pollicis takes origin from tubercle of trapezium and inserts along the lateral border of 1st metacarpal. It may also be implicated in the dislocation of a fractured segment of Bennet fracture

 The images below show the pull of abductor pollicis longus muscle and the repair of Bennet fracture done using K-wire to prevent displacement due to muscle pull

Other options

  • Option A: Extensor pollicis longus takes origin from the posterior shaft of the ulna and adjacent interosseus membrane and inserts on the dorsal surface of base of the distal phalanx of the thumb. It extends the interphalangeal joint of the thumb. Since it is not attached on metacarpal it is less likely to be implicated here
  • Option B: Abductor pollicis brevis takes origin from flexor retinaculum, from scaphoid and trapezium, and inserts over a proximal phalanx of the thumb. Since it is not inserted on the metacarpal, it is not involved in Bennet fracture 
  • Option D: Flexor pollicis brevis originates from the flexor retinaculum and trapezium, whereas a deep part originates from the trapezoid. It inserts on the base of the proximal phalanx of the thumb. Since it is not inserted on the metacarpal, it is not involved in Bennet fracture

A 61-year-old man presented with weight loss, easy fatiguability, and bone pain for 6 months duration. A bone marrow aspirate is shown in the image below. Immunohistochemistry was negative for tDt but was positive for MPO. Cytogenetic studies revealed the presence of t(15:17). What is the likely diagnosis in this case?

The above clinical scenario of an elderly man presenting with anemia, thrombocytopenia, positive MPO in immunohistochemistry, characteristic translocation(15;17), and peripheral smear showing faggot cells is suggestive of acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

AML is a hematopoietic progenitor malignancy that causes immature myeloblast accumulation in the bone marrow.  Incidence increases with age and peaks after 60 years of age. Occupational exposure to benzene leads to epoxide formation which in turn predisposes to the development of AML. Clinically, the patients present with symptoms resulting due to pancytopenia (anemia, neutropenia, thrombocytopenia). There is generalised fatigue, bone pain, bleeding tendencies and an increased risk of recurrent infections. Hemorrhagic complications such as disseminated intravascular coagulation may be seen more commonly in a subtype of AML, acute promyelocytic leukemia.

Other distinctive features of AML include

  • Bone marrow/peripheral smear shows a large, uniform population of cells (myeloblasts) with prominent nucleoli (yellow arrow). It shows the presence of primary cytoplasmic granules
  • Auer rods: needle-shaped azurophilic intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies formed by the fusion of lysosomes. (black arrow)
  • Multiple Auer rods clustered together within a single cell resembling a bundle of sticks known as faggot cells (seen in peripheral smear).
  • This is characteristic of acute promyelocytic leukemia (AML M3) or AML associated with PML-RARɑ fusion gene or t(15;17). Other cytogenetic abnormalities, seen in AML are t(8;21) and inversion 16. 

For acute myeloblastic leukemia (AML) diagnosis, the blast cell count should be ≥20% in the peripheral blood or bone marrow

The treatment of choice for AML-M3 with t(15;17) is all-trans-retinoic acid (ATRA).

Other options:

Option A- Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) arises from immature B (pre-B) or T (pre-T) cells called lymphoblasts. Immunohistochemistry for terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT) is positive in pre-B and pre-T lymphoblasts. Peripheral smear shows lymphoblasts that have condensed chromatin, less conspicuous nucleoli, and smaller amounts of cytoplasm which lacks granules as shown below.

Option B- Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia is associated with the deletions of 13q, 11q, 17q, and trisomy 12q. Lymph nodes are diffusely effaced by small lymphocytes with proliferation centres. The image shows small round lymphocytes and smudge cells seen in CLL.

Option D- Chronic myeloid leukemia is characterised by the presence of a Philadelphia chromosome resulting from reciprocal translocation t(9;22) forming the BCR-ABL fusion gene. They have a hypercellular marrow due to a massively increased number of maturing granulocytic precursors. questions.text: A 20-year-old woman comes to the physician due to irregular menstrual cycles. She is 160 cm tall and weighs 78 kg. You notice she has dark coarse hair on her chin and thinning of hair on her scalp. She also has severe acne on her face and spread over her back. Which of the following do you expect to be reduced in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests that the patient is likely suffering from polycystic ovarian disease (PCOD). In a patient with PCOD, there is a reduced FSH/LH ratio in the serum.

Polycystic ovarian disease is an endocrinopathy in women of reproductive age, affecting multiple systems. Rotterdam criteria is used to diagnose polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). The presence of any two of the three components of this criteria establishes the diagnosis of PCOS.

Rotterdam criteria (ASRM/ESHRE- European society of human reproduction and embryology, 2003):

  • Clinical/biochemical hyperandrogenism
  • Oligo/anovulation
  • Polycystic ovaries on USG

This patient's irregular menstrual cycles (signifying irregular ovulation/ anovulation), obesity (BMI 30.4), coarse dark hair on the chin (hirsutism signifying clinical hyperandrogenism), androgenic baldness (thinning of scalp hair), and severe acne are suggestive of PCOD.

Obesity leads to insulin resistance and hyperinsulinemia. Hyperinsulinemia induces luteinizing hormone (LH) to cause thecal hyperplasia, which in turn increases the production of androgens (testosterone). Androgens are further aromatized in the periphery to form estrogens. Due to increased adipose cells in obesity, there is increased peripheral production of estrogens. This in turn causes a surge in LH in the hypothalamo-pituatry-ovarian axis (HPO axis).

Increased circulating androgens have negative feedback on the HPA to decrease the production of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH). As FSH levels decrease and LH levels increase, there is a low FSH/LH ratio in PCOD patients. 

Hyperinsulinemia and increased androgens also suppress sex-hormone binding globulin levels. This leads to increased levels of free testosterone, which is responsible for hirsutism and acne.

On USG, polycystic ovaries show multiple follicles arranged in a necklace of pearls appearance. (image below)

Related Pearl: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 -80 ng/dL)
    • Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor
    • DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old girl presented to your clinic with a history of fever for the last 24 hours and lower abdominal pain and anorexia for the last 5 days. Her last menstrual period was 10 days ago and she is sexually active with one male partner. On examination, her pulse rate is found to be 98 beats per minute, BP is 118/80 mm of Hg, her temperature is 101.3F. There is generalized abdominal tenderness. On examination per speculum, there is cervical erythema and motion tenderness. There are no lesions on the external genitalia. Microscopy of the cervical discharge shows scant neutrophils and sloughed epithelial cells. McCoy cell culture of the endocervical sample, revealed iodine-stained inclusion bodies as shown below. Which of the following are correct about the likely etiology?

Statement 1. Is a coccobacillus.
Statement 2. Is an obligate intracellular organism.
Statement 3. Is filtrable through standard bacterial filters.
Statement 4. Is a naked dsDNA virus with icosahedral symmetry.
questions.solution:
The patient’s presentation is typical of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). Chlamydia trachomatis is the most likely organism in this case suggested by the presence of characteristic iodine-stained inclusion bodies in the McCoy cells cultures of the patient's endocervical sample. It is the most common cause of bacterial sexually transmitted infection in both men and women. 

Chlamydia is a gram-negative coccobacillus that has the following features-

  • They are obligate intracellular organisms as they lack the enzymes for ATP synthesis, and are hence dependent entirely on the host cell. 
  • They can exist in two states.
    • Extracellular infective form called the elementary body.
    • Intracellular non-infective form called the reticulate body. These reticulate bodies are found inside a membrane-bound compartment called the "inclusion body" which can be visualized within infected epithelial cells by iodine or Giemsa stain. 
  • They are small bacteria about 0.2-0.3 microns in size and are hence filtrable through the pore size of standard bacterial filters.

Therefore, among the given statements, statement 4 is wrong because Chlamydia is a bacterial organism, not a dsDNA virus with icosahedral symmetry. This describes the human papillomavirus that can cause anogenital warts, cervical dysplasia, and anogenital neoplasia, but not PID.

questions.text: An oncologist is studying the effect of postoperative radiotherapy on the survival rate of patients with Non-small cell lung cancer. He finds no survival benefit in 30 patients who were given postoperative radiotherapy compared to 30 patients who weren't given radiotherapy. (p=0.4). He feels that the results are non-significant due to the smaller sample size and missing the beneficial effect of radiotherapy. He, therefore, repeats the study with more sample size. Which of the following will happen as a result of increasing sample size?

choices.text: Decrease in probability of type 1 error
Increase in probability of type 2 error
Increase in probability of type 1 error
Decrease in probability of type 2 error

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, a p-value of 0.4 (>0.05) suggests that if at all any survival benefit was observed it was by chance. With an increase in the sample size, the probability of a Type II error (given a false null hypothesis) decreases, however the maximum probability of a Type I error (given a true null hypothesis) remains alpha by definition.

Let's say in reality, radiotherapy has no survival benefit(null hypothesis). Now, this test is conducted to see/confirm whether or not there is any effect of radiotherapy. We conduct the study and calculate the p-value. P-value tells us about the probability of an outcome(here - no survival benefit) given the hypothesis.  If the p-value is less than a predecided 0.05, we infer that the results are statistically significant and not just by chance. In this case, since the p-value is more than 0.05, we infer that the outcome (here - no survival benefit), is due to chance, there is actually no significant survival benefit. 

But what if, this survival benefit is observed in very few patients( say 1 in 100 or 1 in 300). Then this study is less likely to detect it with such a small sample size. And we might accept the null hypothesis (no survival benefit with radiotherapy), even though there it is not true. This would result in a false-negative result/ type II error. 

So the researcher wanted to repeat the study, with more sample size, to decrease the type 2 error.

 

Type I error (ɑ): Null hypothesis (H0) is incorrectly rejected i.e. H0 is rejected by the study when in reality it is true.

  • False-positive error
  • ɑ = you accused an innocent man  

Type II error (β): Null hypothesis is incorrectly accepted i.e. H0 is not rejected by the study when in reality it is false.

  • False-negative error
  • β  = you blindly let a guilty man go free  

Power (1-β): the probability of rejecting the null hypothesis when it is false. 

  • ↑ Power and ↓ β by:
    • ↑ sample size
    • ↑ expected effect size
    • ↑ precision of measurement

Related Pearl: Concepts in Hypothesis Testing

Probability value (p value)

  • A probability value is the probability of an outcome given the hypothesis.
  • It is not the probability of the hypothesis given the outcome, although the probability of the given hypothesis is not ignored.
  • If the probability of an outcome is sufficiently low, we have evidence that the hypothesis is false.
  • It is also called the p value.

The Null Hypothesis and Alternative Hypothesis

  • The hypothesis that an apparent effect or outcome is only due to chance is a null hypothesis.
  • In other words, a null hypothesis is one where there is no difference between the specified sample and population and any observed difference is due to chance or some other error.
  • A null hypothesis is represented by H0.
  • If the null hypothesis is rejected as false, then there is an alternative or experimental hypothesis (HA), which is logically accepted.

Criterion or Significance Level (α)

  • If the probability value of an outcome is sufficiently low, then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • This point below which we would define the probability value as being low enough to reject the null hypothesis is called the criterion or significance level or α (alpha) level.
  • When the null hypothesis is rejected, the effect or outcome is said to be statistically significant.
  • By convention (but not always), the level of α is 0.05, i.e., if the probability value of an outcome is less than or equal to 0.05 (p value ≤ 0.05), then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • If it is greater than 0.05, then the null hypothesis is accepted.
  • Although by convention the level of α is 0.05, it can be lower but cannot be any higher.

Type I Error

  • The interpretation of p value ≤ 0.05 is that an investigator can be 95% sure that the result was not obtained by chance.
  • It also means that there is a 5% probability that the result was obtained by chance.
  • From this, we can deduce that the null hypothesis might indeed be true even though we rejected it.
  • This is a type I error. In other words, when an alternative hypothesis is accepted even when it is false and the null hypothesis is true, it is a type I error or false positive error.
  • It is also called an alpha (α) error as it is related to the criterion α.
  • The lower the α level, the lower the rate of a type I error being made.
  • Thus, it can be said that α is the maximum tolerable probability that a type I error is being made and that the p value is the probability that a significant difference is declared when there is none.

Type II Error

  • The error that is made by rejecting an alternative hypothesis when it is true or failing to reject a null hypothesis when it is false is called a type II error.
  • It is also called a false negative error and more commonly, as a beta (β) error.
  • If the null hypothesis is false, then the probability of a type II error is β.
  • The power of a statistical test is indicated by 1–β.

Power of a Test

  • The power of a test is the ability of a statistical test to avoid a type II error, which depends on its ability to detect a false null hypothesis.
  • It is equal to 1–β, which is the probability that a false null hypothesis will be rejected.
  • By convention, a test is required to have a power of 0.8 (or a β of 0.2) to be acceptable. This is to say that a study that has less than 80% chance of detecting a false null hypothesis is unacceptable.
  • Type I errors are easily reduced by reducing the criterion α.
  • A test's power will increase in the following conditions:
    • If α increases, but this will increase the chance of a type I error.
    • If the difference between the sample mean and hypothesized mean increases. This is also called effect size.
    • If sampling error decreases.
    • If the sample size (n) increases.

questions.text: You are working as an internal medicine consultant at a private practice. A patient with chronic renal disease is admitted under you requiring hemodialysis. However, you advise only diet and fluid control and strict adherence to instructions and keep him on observation. But the patient continues to take ayurvedic supplements and sometimes skips the instructions without disclosing it. His conditions worsen and he develops difficulty in breathing. His attendant files a complaint in court alleging the negligence of the doctor. Which of the following acts as a defense for the doctor in court?
questions.solution:
In the given case, since the patient did not adhere to the proper instructions of the doctor, it was partly or wholly his fault. This is termed contributory negligence. Proper documentation as to how ordinary care was not exercised on part of the patient can be useful in a court of law.

Contributory negligence occurs when a patient or his personal attendant shows unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care, which when combined with the negligence of the doctor, has contributed to the injury. In this case, the patient’s or attendant’s negligence should be the direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred

Defenses Against Negligence

  • No duty owed to the plaintiff
  • Duty discharged according to prevailing standards
  • Misadventure - may be therapeutic, diagnostic, and experimental
  • Error of judgment
  • Contributory negligence - the absence of ordinary care on the part of the patient or his personal attendant

 Option A Vicarious liability is not a defense against professional negligence. Vicarious liability(liability for the act of another): An employer is responsible not only for his own negligence but also for the negligence of his employees.

Option B Res ipsa loquitur means 'the thing speaks for itself. It is used as supportive evidence of negligence on part of the doctor. Say leaving behind scalpel or scissors whilst operating leading to sepsis/peritonitis speaks for itself.

Option C Therapeutic misadventure may serve as a defense against negligence. It basically refers to an adverse outcome that could not have been anticipated despite reasonable care. Say a rare side effect of a drug or blood loss due to an anomalous artery despite exercising caution.

Related Pearl: Contributory negligence

Contributory negligence occurs when a patient or his personal attendant shows unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care, which when combined with the negligence of the doctor, has contributed to the injury. In this case, the patient’s or attendant’s negligence should be the direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred.

So, contributory negligence occurs when both the doctor and patient are negligent. The direct or proximate cause of the injury should be the patient’s negligence, which means that if the patient was not negligent, the injury could have been prevented.

Contributory negligence usually occurs when the doctor is negligent and the patient:

  • Fails to give an accurate medical history, and as a result, the doctor may misdiagnose or mistreat the patient.
  • Fails to follow the doctor’s instructions
  • Refuses to take the treatment
  • Leaves the hospital against doctor’s advice
  • Does not inform the doctor or seek further medical assistance if the symptoms persist or worsens.

Contributory negligence is a defence for doctor’s negligence in civil cases. However, from case to case, the liability of a doctor may vary from complete non-liability to substantial liability for the damages. Under the doctrine of comparative negligence, the court has the right to hold both parties liable for their negligent actions.

Limitations / Exceptions to contributory negligence:

A. The doctor will be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. The doctor failed to provide proper instructions to the patient

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and did not tell the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (no proper instruction). The patient develops numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

 2. Last clear chance doctrine: It is applicable when the doctor fails to take necessary action to prevent damage due to a negligent act of the patient, even after getting a clear chance to take such action.

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and told the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (gave proper instruction). The patient developed numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). Next day patient informed the doctor, but the doctor did not remove the cast and said he was busy (There was a clear last chance, but the doctor neglected again). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

B. The doctor/person will not be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. Avoidable consequences rule: It occurs when an injury is caused due to doctor’s negligence, and the patient has done a negligent act, which further aggravated the injury caused by the doctor, and the patient could have avoided the consequence by not doing such act. In such cases, the doctor need not pay anything, and the patient will be held guilty.

  • Ex: A patient had a lacerated wound. The doctor examined the patient and had not done any dressing or provided any antibiotics (the doctor is negligent). However, the doctor instructed the patient to avoid contamination and asked him to visit the clinic next week. When the patient went home, he applied cow dung on his wound every day thinking that the wound would heal faster and didn't visit the doctor after one week. The wound got infected and developed pus and aggravated the injury.
  • Here, despite the doctor being negligent in the first instance, the patient is responsible for his injury as he performed an unnecessary, avoidable act, which aggravated the injury. The doctor need not pay anything.

2. Good Samaritan doctrine: A person who assists another person who is in serious danger cannot be charged with contributory negligence. unless such assistance is reckless or rash.

  • Ex: A person was travelling on a road and saw a car accident, where the victim was unconscious and was stuck inside the car. He called the ambulance. The paramedical staff instructed him not to mobilize the victim until they arrived. Meanwhile, the car was caught in fire (serious danger), and the person tried to remove the victim carefully out of the car (assisted the victim and was not reckless). However, the victim already had a cervical bone fracture due to the accident, which got mobilized while he was being removed out of the car and as a result, suffered an injury to the spine that led to paralysis (victim’s injury was aggravated). In such a case, the good samaritan doctrine would apply and the person who tried to help, will not be charged under contributory negligence.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman who is two weeks postpartum was brought by her husband due to extreme tiredness. She gave birth to a healthy baby at term through vaginal delivery. However, post-delivery, she had post-partum hemorrhage and received 3 units of packed red blood cells. He reports that she has been unable to produce breast milk. On examination, her pulse is 96 bpm and blood pressure is 80/50 mm of Hg.  Which of the following sets of serum findings are likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given presentation of fatigue, failure of lactation, and hypotension following post-partum haemorrhage is suggestive of Sheehan's syndrome, which causes secondary adrenal insufficiency. There is a decrease in the adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) which results in decreased cortisol.

Pituitary apoplexy is a hemorrhagic infarction of large pituitary adenomas or pituitary infarction due to traumatic major blood loss. If this blood loss occurs during delivery, it's called Sheehan's syndrome. The hyperplastic enlargement of the pituitary, which occurs normally during pregnancy, increases the risk for haemorrhage and infarction. 

It can present acutely with sudden onset of headache, nausea, visual deficits and in severe cases, severe hypoglycemia, hypotension and shock, CNS haemorrhage and death.
Also, it can present late with the following features:
  • Lactation failure due to prolactin deficiency
  • Amenorrhea due to anovulation caused by reduced gonadotropin activity
  • Loss of pubic and axillary hair
  • Hypothyroidism due to decreased TSH secretion 
  • Adrenal insufficiency due to low ACTH

Damage to the pituitary results in decreased production of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) causing secondary adrenal insufficiency which in turn results in decreased cortisol levels. In secondary adrenal insufficiency, aldosterone production is relatively preserved as it is independent of ACTH. It is the most life-threatening complication.

Treatment is by hormone replacement - first glucocorticoids, later - thyroid hormone, sex steroids, vasopressin, and growth hormones are given. If there is evidence of progressive visual loss, cranial nerve involvement, or loss of consciousness, immediate surgical decompression must be carried out.

 

Other options:

Options A and B: This patient does not have any signs of hypercortisolism like moon facies, buffalo hump, truncal obesity, purple striae, or hypertension. Cortisol production is decreased in secondary adrenal insufficiency.

Option C: Decreased cortisol and increased ACTH is seen in primary adrenal insufficiency. Cortisol production is decreased due to a primary adrenal disorder which in turn causes an increase in ACTH by negative feedback. These patients present with symptoms of low cortisol such as fatigue, loss of energy, and hypotension. A distinguishing feature in primary adrenal insufficiency is hyperpigmentation, due to stimulation of melanocytes by excess ACTH (molecular similarity with melanocyte-stimulating hormone). In primary adrenal insufficiency, aldosterone and adrenal androgen levels are also decreased.

questions.text: Mr Rao, a 65-year-old man comes with complaints of shortness of breath. He says it started 3 years ago when he used to carry heavy loads up and down a flight of stairs for his job. He changed his job because of the shortness of breath. He complains that over the years it has progressively worsened. He has a 40 pack-year smoking history and he continues to smoke 5-6 cigarettes per day. He had a myocardial infarction 8 years ago and had undergone stent replacement for the same. His past history is also significant for chronic bronchitis for 5 years. He has had one exacerbation in the last 1 year treated with oral antibiotics. Auscultation reveals decreased breath sounds, bilaterally. Which of the following can you expect to be increased in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has chronic obstructive pulmonary diseases (COPD) and functional residual capacity is increased in this condition. 

In spirometry,

  • Forced vital capacity (FVC) is the total exhaled volume
  • Forced expiratory volume 1( FEV1) is the volume exhaled in the first second

FVC, FEV1 along with FEV1/ FVC ratio are the most important parameters in spirometric testing useful in the assessment of obstructive and restrictive lung diseases. 

This patient has chronic bronchitis, which is a type of obstructive lung disease. In obstructive lung diseases, the obstruction in the airways reduces both FEV1 and FVC. However, the decrease in FEV1 is greater than the reduction in FVC. As a result, the ratio FEV1/FVC also decreases.

Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is the volume of air present in the lungs at the end of passive expiration. It is residual volume (RV) + expiratory reserve volume (ERV). 

In COPD, airway obstruction results in air trapping in the distal bronchioles. This results in increased RV which in turn increases the FRC. However, increased total lung capacity indicates hyperinflation.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to your clinic with complaints of rashes on her body that began around 2 days ago. She first noticed them on her hands and now several of them are present on both her arms and chest. She is otherwise asymptomatic and is not currently on any medication. On examination, pulse rate is 82, BP is 110/72 mm Hg, and the temperature is 98.6F.  There are several, circular lesions on her hands, arms, trunk, and neck. They are reddish plaques varying in size, ranging anywhere between 1-5 centimeters. There is a dark red center surrounded by a paler red zone, which is in turn encircled by a dark red border. Additionally, you notice that there are a few small lesions along her lower lip, as shown in the image below which are different from the rashes described before. What is the most likely diagnosis of the rash seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Image shows small, closely grouped vesicles on an inflamed base and is characteristic of Herpes Labialis or Cold sore. Hence, the most likely diagnosis of the rash described is erythema multiforme.

It is a skin condition that is caused due to a type IV hypersensitivity reaction to certain infections and drugs. The majority of the cases are associated with herpes simplex virus infection, as in this patient. The herpes infection usually precedes the skin eruption by 3-14 days. 

The lesions in erythema multiforme start to appear over the dorsal surface of the hands and feet. Palms and soles may also be involved. They then spread towards the trunk, followed by the face and neck. They tend to involve the upper limb more than the lower limb. Mucosa may also be involved.

These lesions appear and evolve over a day. At the time of clinical presentation, the skin eruption may contain different kinds of lesions both typical and atypical, all at various stages of development, lending the name "multiforme"-

  • Typical lesions of erythema multiforme are called target lesions or iris lesions. They are circular and have three distinct zones. A dark red center with skin changes including blisters or crusts. It is encircled by a pale zone that is caused due to edema. This second zone is surrounded by a dark red line.
  • Atypical lesions contain eruptions that have only two zones or an indistinct border.

Erythema multiforme is self-resolving and is treated symptomatically. Associated herpes simplex virus infections can be treated with oral acyclovir. 

The clinical description of the rash with the presence of coexisting herpes labialis are strongly suggestive of erythema multiforme.

Other options-

Option B- Erythema marginatum is seen in acute rheumatic fever. They appear as pink patches that clear centrally and have a serpiginous, spreading edge. It is evanescent, meaning it may disappear only to reappear at another site. It is usually seen on the trunk, and on the limbs, but it is rarely seen involving the face.

 

Option C- Erythema nodosum is inflammation of the subcutaneous fat (panniculitis). It is associated with sarcoidosis, tuberculosis, and drug reactions.

 

Option D- Erythema migrans is the characteristic lesion of Lyme disease caused by Borrelia burgdorferi. It also has a characteristic bulls-eye appearance. But, it is typically seen at the site of the tick bite. It is an expanding rash and may increase by 2-3 diameters per day.
